title: How different is Siberia to Russia? - Quora

response.answer_text: How different is Russia east of the Urals from Russia west of the Urals? That's a better way to phrase the question, and it's a good question. Some places in Siberia (Russia east of the Urals) are very, very different from the rest of Russia. In some places, Russian is barely even spoken. There are places in Siberia where the only people are bands of nomadic caribou herders who speak Asian languages. There are also settled villages of non-Russian speakers with customs very different from Russian customs. But on the the whole, Siberia is very Russian. Large cities are inhabited by large Russian populations. The Russian spoken east of the Urals does not sound a lot different from the Russian spoken in, say, Moscow or Leningrad. To my ears, it's no greater a difference than that between the English spoken in Pennsylvania and the English spoken in Utah, for example. So some things about Siberia are very different from the rest of Russia and some things are very much the same.

How different? First Siberia IS Russia. Second - Siberia is VAST and mostly unpopulated, only ~20% of Russia’s population lives there - climate is too severe. Remember this planet “point of cold” where the lowest Northern semisphere temperature was registered (minus 57 C) is Siberia (Oimyakon), Culture and people at first look are not much different, but if you look closer they are: the people are tougher and more direct and honest. Not so much in cities but in small towns and villages. During WWII if you were at a front line the best you could hope that on your flanks are Siberian divisions: they were made of steel, no talk, fought till the end. I speak out of personal experience having visited Western Siberia small town/village: “Westerners” i.e. Russians from Central Russia are not mixing with the locals - the town had almost official line - here are the locals, there are the “Westerners”. Obviously everything I say is just personal opinion. So take it with a grain of salt.

Well, first of all, Siberia is Russia. Although, it is quite vast and is home to many nationalities, in any town or village you will be able to see some Soviet architecture or even pre-revolutional buildings (those are rare). That what generally forms the ‘face’ of Russia, besides the people. I was born in Western Siberia and managed to travel around there a bit, though, everyone’s opinion or impression might be different. I would say Siberia is the true Russia, cold, wild and beautiful.
